data.title: Family List of Cases
data.text:
This list contains certain frequently relied on cases which are supplied to judges hearing family law cases in the Superior Court of Justice as directed by the provisions in the Consolidated Provincial Practice Direction that address often cited family law cases.

The cases in question appear on this list under various headings or topics which are not in any way intended to provide legal advice.

Parties in family law proceedings in the Superior Court of Justice need no longer include authorities on this list in any book of authorities relied on. However, extracts from those authorities which counsel intend to refer to the court shall be included in the factum or book of authorities.

Family Law Cases

Parenting

Rawluk v. Rawluk, [1990] 1 S.C.R. 70

Prejudgment and Postjudgment Interest

Katsigiannis v. Kottick-Katsigiannis (2001), 55 O.R. (3d) 456 (C.A.) [subjective approach to acquiescence]

Finizio v. Scoppio-Finizio (1999), 46 O.R. (3d) 226 (C.A.) [adjustment periods]

Ellis v. Wentzell-Ellis, 2010 ONCA 347

R.M. v. J.S., 2013 ABCA 441 [objections of child]

Office of the Children’s Lawyer v. Balev, 2018 SCC 16 [habitual residence, time-limited consent, unilateral changes to child’s residence]

Ludwig v. Ludwig, 2019 ONCA 680 [child removed from jurisdiction, habitual residence]

Contempt/Striking Pleadings

Dickie v. Dickie, 2007 SCC 8 [jurisdiction to refuse to hear appeal based on breach of prior court orders]

Chiaramonte v. Chiaramonte, 2013 ONCA 641 [striking of pleadings as a remedy of last resort, should be done on proper evidentiary record]

Kovachis v. Kovachis, 2013 ONCA 663 [pleadings should be only be struck in exceptional circumstances where no other remedy would suffice, consideration to be given to importance of failure to comply]

Manchanda v. Thethi, 2016 ONCA 909 [conduct exceptional and egregious warranting the striking of pleadings]

Mullin v. Sherlock, 2018 ONCA 1063

Declaration of Parentage Cases

Note on legislation: On January 1, 2017, the All Families Are Equal Act, 2016, came into force. The legislation amends the Children’s Law Reform Act and 40 other statutes. The amendments provide a streamlined process for the legal recognition of parents who use a surrogate and reduces the need for parents who use assisted reproduction to have to go to court to have their parental status recognized in law.

Trociuk v. British Columbia (Attorney General),2003 SCC 34 [unconstitutional for legislation to allow arbitrary exclusion of father from birth registration process, significance of fathers’ interests and dignity]

v. B.B., 2007 ONCA 2 [declaration of third parent pursuant to parens patriae jurisdiction, importance of declaration]

Raft v. Shortt (1986), 54 O.R. (2d) 768 (H.C.) [no declaration of non-parentage under CLRA but available under CJA, issue estoppel, blood tests]

R. v. L.H., 2002 CanLII 76705 (S.C.) [surrogacy, birth registration, custody, declaration of non-parentage under CJA, best interests of the child, sealing court file]

Low v. Low (1994), 114 D.L.R.(4th) 709(Ont. S.C.) [anonymous sperm donor, standing in the place of a parent, CLRA declaration, access]

Rypkema v. British Columbia, 2003 BCSC 1784 [surrogacy, birth registration, genetic parents]

S.K. v. T.L.T.(2003), 168 O.A.C. 73 (C.A.) [sealing court file, best interests of the child]

v. P. (1982),35 O.R. (2d) 325 (S.C.) [support, delaying exchange of financial information, sealing court file]

Standard of Review

Housen v. Nikolaisen, 2002 SCC 33 [standard of review is palpable and overriding error]

(H.) v. Canada (Attorney General), 2005 SCC 25

Deference

(G.C.) v. New Brunswick (Minister of Health and Community Services), [1988] 1 S.C.R. 1073 [deference should be given to trial judge]

New Brunswick (Minister of Health and Community Services) v. L. (M.), [1998] 2 S.C.R. 534 [deference should be given to trial judge]

Hickey v. Hickey, [1999] 2 S.C.R. 518 [need for deference in family law cases]

Duty to Give Reasons

v. Sheppard,2002 SCC 26 [why a duty to give reasons]

Lawson v. Lawson(2006), 81 O.R. (3d) 321 (C.A.) [tension between right to adequate reasons and deference]

Young v. Young(2003), 63 O.R. (3d) 112 (C.A.) [rationale for the need to give reasons in family law context]

Adequacy of Reasons

v. Sheppard, 2002 SCC 26 [functional test]

v. Gagnon, 2006 SCC 17 [two stage analysis for functional test]

Appeal of Costs

Mete v. Guardian Insurance Co. of Canada(1998), 165 D.L.R. (4th) 457 (Ont. C.A.) [high discretion given to costs award]

Hamilton v. Open Window Bakery Ltd., 2004 SCC 9 [costs award should only be set aside if there is an error in principle or award is plainly wrong]

Reasonable Apprehension of Bias

Children’s Aid Society of the Regional Municipality of Waterloo v. R.C.,2009 ONCA 840 [active participation of trial judge in child protection case does not necessarily indicate bias]

R. v. S. (R.D.), [1997] 3 S.C.R. 484

Committee for Justice and Liberty v. National Energy Board, [1978] 1 S.C.R. 369

Wewaykum Indian Band v. Canada,2003 SCC 45

Appeal from an Interim Order

Sypher v. Sypher (1986), 2 R.F.L. (3d) 413 (Ont. C.A.) [the court should not interfere with an interim order unless the order is clearly wrong and exceeds the wide ambit of reasonable solutions]

Fresh Evidence on Appeal

Catholic Children’s Aid Society of Metropolitan Toronto v. M. (C.), [1994] 2 S.C.R. 165 [test for the admission of fresh evidence on appeal]

Palmer v. The Queen, [1980] 1 S.C.R. 759

Often-Cited Child Protection Cases

Note on legislation: Ontario has passed the Child, Youth and Family Services Act (CYFSA), most of which entered into force on April 30, 2018. The CYFSA introduced several changes to child protection proceedings which may impact the relevance of these cases.

Interpretation

Syl Apps Secure Treatment v. B.D., 2007 SCC 38 [statutory duty to protect best interests of the child transcends common law duties to the child’s family]

Jurisdiction

Winnipeg Child & Family Services (Northwest Area) v. G. (D.F.), [1997] 3 S.C.R. 925 [the parens patriae jurisdiction of the court does not extend to unborn children and thus cannot support the detention of an expectant mother]

(C.) v. Catholic Children’s Aid Society of Hamilton-Wentworth(1998), 40 O.R. (3d) 334 (C.A.) [the procedure under the Child and Family Services Act is paramount thereby precluding an order for custody under the CLRA of a Crown Ward/child in extended society care]

First Nations, Inuk or Métis Child

Bruce Grey Child and Family Services v. A.B.-C, 2018 ONCJ 516 [there must be an evidentiary basis for finding under s. 90(2)(b) of the CYFSA that a child is a First Nations, Inuk or Métis child]

Duties of Society

Children’s Aid Society of Hamilton v. E.O., 2009 CanLII 72087 (Ont. S.C.) [unjustifiable delay unnecessarily clouding the issues]

Hastings Children’s Aid Society v. S.(A.), 2007 ONCJ 694, at paras. 119-120 [duty of society to act fairly and provide frank disclosure]

Onus of Proof

Temporary Care and Custody Hearings

Children’s Aid Society of Ottawa-Carleton v. T., 2000 CanLII 21157(Ont. S.C.) [test for temporary care and custody requires CAS to establish, on credible and trustworthy evidence, reasonable grounds to believe that there is a real possibility that, if the child is returned to his or her parents, it is more probable than not that he or she will suffer harm]

Children’s Aid Society of Waterloo (Regional Municipality) v. B.A., 2004 CanLII 12742(Ont. S.C.) [test for making a temporary placement order with a third party is a reasonable likelihood of risk on something less than the ordinary civil onus of proof on the balance of probabilities]

Children’s Aid Society of Toronto v. M.A. 2002 CanLII 45665 (Ont. C.J.) [standard of evidence on a temporary care and custody hearing]

Children’s Aid Society of Algoma v. S.P. 2011 CanLII 93 (Ont. C.J.) [application of the maximum contact principle]

Section 57.1 custody orders

Windsor-Essex Children’s Aid Society v. J.D.,2017 ONCJ 20 [a final access order need not be made at the same time as the custody order, provided that it is made in the same case.]

Variation of orders pending trial

Children’s Aid Society of Toronto v. K.D.,2011 ONCJ 55 [test for variation of temporary orders]

Children’s Aid Society of the County of Simcoe v. B. (B.J.), (2005), 20 R.F.L. (6th) 74 (Ont. S.C.) [Variation of a temporary care order is a two-stage process. The party wishing the changes must show: (a) that there has been a material change; (b) if there has been a material change, the court must consider the situation using the same risk criteria set out in s. 51.]

Children’s Aid Society of Metropolitan Toronto v. C.Y. (1993), 45 R.F.L. (3d) 24, (Ont. S.C.) [on an adjournment of a status review application and a request for a change in interim care and custody pending trial, the test is best interests and not the risk test set out in s. 51]

Final Disposition

H. v. McDougall,2008 SCC 53 [There is only one standard of proof in a civil case and that is proof on a balance of probabilities. There are no degrees of probability within that civil standard.]

Children’s Aid Society of the Niagara Region v. P.L.R., [2005] O.T.C. 255 (Ont. S.C.) [The onus is on the CAS and while the evidence must be convincing, the ordinary civil burden has not been changed.]

Re Brown (1976), 9 O.R. (2d) 185 (Co. Ct.) [Intervention is only justified when the level of care falls below that which no child in this country should be subjected to.]

Catholic Children’s Aid Society of Hamilton v. J.I., 2006 CanLII 19432(Ont. S.C.) [Should not to judge parent by a middle-class yardstick, one that imposes unrealistic and unfair middle-class standards of child care upon a poor parent of extremely limited potential, provided that the standard used is not contrary to the child’s best interests.]

Procedural Issues

Children’s Aid Society of London and Middlesex v. H. (S), [2002] O.T.C. 916 (S.C.) [parties to a child protection case are not limited by the legislation and may be supplemented by the Court]

G.(C.) v. Catholic Children’s Aid Society of Hamilton-Wentworth (1998), 40 O.R. (3d) 334 (C.A.) [foster parents may not apply for a status review hearing]

Catholic Children’s Aid Society of Toronto v. B. (D.), 2002 CanLII 53290 (Ont. C.J.) [the test for leave to withdraw]

Children’s Aid Society of the Region of Peel v. L.M., 2018 ONSC 3633 [s. 7 charter rights and state funded counsel]

Catholic Children’s Aid Society of Toronto v. J.R.C., 2015 ONCJ 729 [s. 7 Charter rights and state funded counsel]

Time Line Restrictions

Children’s Aid Society of Ottawa-Carleton v. K.F., 2003 CanLII 67559 (Ont. S.C.) [the court’s discretion to extend the statutory time limit that a child can be in care under s. 70(4) of the legislation must be based on the best interests of the child]

Child’s Rights as a Party

Office of the Children’s Lawyer v Office of the Children’s Lawyer v. Catholic Children’s Aid Society of Toronto, 2020 ONSC 4310 [child’s rights in a CYFSA proceeding]

Appointing Counsel For the Subject Children

R. v. Children’s Aid Society of Hamilton (2004), 70 O.R. (3d) 618(Ont. S.C.) [court may direct counsel be appointed for child under CFSA, which is different than a referral to the OCL for consideration under the CLRA]

Statutory Pathway For Protection Hearing

Children’s Aid Society of Toronto v. T.L. and E.B.,2010 ONSC 1376 [statutory pathway for disposition hearings]

(R.) v. Children’s Aid Society of Metropolitan Toronto(1995), 21 O.R. (3d) 724 (S.C.) [importance of considering family/community placements and less restrictive alternatives throughout]

Protection Findings

Children’s Aid Society of the Niagara Region v. T.P.(2003), 35 R.F.L. (5th) 290 (Ont. S.C.) [(a) Intention is not required to prove risk of likely harm; (b) Harm must be more than trifling; (c) The finding is based on the situation at the time of apprehension]

Children’s Aid Society of Hamilton v. C.(M.) (2003), 36 R.F.L. (5th) 46 (Ont. S.C.) [the relevant time for making a protection finding is not limited to the time of the apprehension and the initiation of the case]

Jewish Family and Child Service v. K. (R.),2008 ONCJ 774 [domestic violence places a child at risk of harm]

Status Review Hearings

Catholic Children’s Aid Society of Metro Toronto v. M.(C.), [1994] 2 S.C.R. 165 [court’s function on a status review hearing; Status review hearing is a two part process]

Catholic Children’s Aid Society of Hamilton v. M.A.M., 2003 CanLII 71148 (Ont. S.C.) [the repealing of subsection 65(3) is consistent with the overall thrust of the amendments which focus the Court’s attention on the child in preference to the parent]

Children’s Aid Society of Ottawa v. C.W., 2008 CanLII 13181(Ont. S.C.) [A status review hearing cannot retry the original need for a protection order. The issue is whether the child continues to be in need of protection and, if so, what order is in the best interests of the child.]

Children’s Aid Society of the Region of Peel v. M.J.W. (1995), 23 O.R. (3d) 174(C.A.) [role of familial plans in status review hearings as they relate to the least restrictive placement concept]

Evidentiary Issues

v. Khan, [1990] 2 S.C.R. 531 [ability of child to testify and when to accept evidence of child’s spontaneous statements]

v. Blackman,2008 SCC 37 [principled approach to the admissibility of hearsay evidence]

Stefureak v. Chambers (2004), 6 R.F.L. (6th) 212 (Ont. S.C.) [admissibility of hearsay evidence of a child’s out-of-court statements is governed by necessity and reliability]

C. v. G.P (2003), 41 R.F.L. (5th) 250 (Ont. S.C.) [considerations governing the compelled testimony of a child]

Children’s Aid society of Toronto v. L.L., 2010 ONCJ 48 [admissibility of first-hand hearsay business records is governed by relevancy]

Children’s Aid Society of the Regional Municipality of Waterloo v. C. (R.), 1994 CanLII 4520(Ont. C.J.) [boundaries for evidence on past parenting conduct]

Children’s Aid Society of Niagara Region v. D.P. (2003), 36 R.F.L. (5th) 265 (Ont. S.C.) [if adoptability is an issue, expert evidence is required]

(R.) v. Children’s Aid Society of the Niagara Region(2002), 34 R.F.L. (5th) 44 (Ont. C.A.) [the Act does not envisage a contest between members of a child’s family and a foster parent at a hearing to declare whether the child should be declared to be a society or Crown ward]

Children’s Aid Society of Toronto v. B.H., [2007] O.J. No. 2446 (C.J.), [society obliged to provide a balanced perspective of the case]

Children’s Aid Society of Algoma v. P.(D.),2006 ONCJ 170, [evidence adduced under s.74 of the CFSA must be relevant]

L. v. N.B. (2005),252 D.L.R. (4th) 508 (Ont. C.A.) [disclosure of youth records]

Children’s Aid Society of the Niagara Region v. D.M., [2002] O.J. No. 1421 (S.C.) [opinion evidence]

Access

Children’s Aid Society of Toronto v. J.G. 2020 ONCA 415 [new approach to access to a child in extended society care, no presumptive rule against access]

Children’s Aid Society of Toronto v. D.P. (2005), 19 R.F.L. (6th) 267(Ont. C.A.) [even where a Crown wardship order gives no right of access to a parent, the CAS may, as a custodial parent of the child, permit the parent to visit the child unless the order expressly states that there will be no contact]

Jewish Family and Child Service of Greater Toronto v. H.B.S., 2012 ONCJ 663 [temporary access]

Children’s Aid Society of Toronto v. E.U., 2014 ONCJ 299 [child as access holder, not parents]

Children’s Aid Society of Toronto v. Y.M., 2019 ONCJ 489 [the access holder and sibling access]

Children’s Aid Society of the Niagara Region v. J.C., 281 D.L.R. (4th) 328 (Ont. Div. Ct.) [sibling access]

Children’s Aid Society of Toronto v. R. M. 2017 ONCJ 784 [variation of access]

Public Guardian and Trustee motions

Children’s Aid Society of the Niagara Region v. W.D., 43 R.F.L. (5th) 286 (Ont. S.C.) [test for mental capacity]

York Region Children’s Aid Society v J.H.V. et al., 2016 ONSC 4996 [test for mental capacity; test for incapacity is objective]

C. v. Children’s Aid Society of Toronto, [2007] O.J. No. 5613 (Ont. S.C.) [lack of sophistication, education or cultural differences are not sufficient evidence of mental incapacity]

Charter Issues

Winnipeg Child and Family Services v. K.L.W., 2000 SCC 48 [state apprehensions without prior judicial authorization in non-emergency situations do not violate s. 7 of the Charter, so long as there is a prompt post-apprehension hearing]

(R.) v. Children’s Aid Society of Metropolitan Toronto, [1995] 1 S.C.R. 315 [crown wardship violates parents’ s. 7 rights to refuse medical treatment for their child, but does not violate the principles of fundamental justice]

C. v. Manitoba (Director of Child and Family Services),2009 SCC 30 [court’s ability to mandate treatment for children under 16 years of age does not violate ss. 2(a), 7, or 15 of the Charter]

New Brunswick (Minister of Health and Community Services) v. G.(J.), [1999] 3 S.C.R. 46 [state-funded counsel required by s. 7 in the context of custody proceedings involving the state]

Catholic Children’s Aid Society of Metropolitan Toronto v. M.(C.), [1994] 2 S.C.R. 165 [section 11(b) of the Charter does not apply to the Child and Family Services Act]

Catholic Children’s Aid Society of Metropolitan Toronto v. T.S.(1989), 69 O.R. (2d) 189 (C.A.) [denial of birth parent’s access to child after adoption is constitutional]

Summary Judgment Motions

Hryniak v. Mauldin,2014 SCC 7 [test for summary judgment]

Kawartha-Haliburton Children’s Aid Society v. M.W., 2019 ONCA 316 [proper approach to summary judgment in child protection matters]

Children’s Aid Society of Toronto v. T. (K.), 2000 CanLII 20578(Ont. C.J.) [where a prima facie case for summary judgment is made out, the responding party must present evidence to show there is a genuine issue for trial]

Children’s Aid Society of Toronto v. R.H., 2000 CanLII 3158(Ont. C.J.) [specific facts reflecting a genuine issue for trial must be provided, not simply a heartfelt expression of a desire to resume care of the child.] [Mere denials do not raise triable issue of fact]

A. v. Jewish Family and Child Services, [2001] O.J. No. 47 (S.C.) [not every disputed fact or question gives rise to a finding that there is a genuine issue for trial]

B. v. S.G.(2001), 199 D.L.R. (4th) 554 (Ont. S.C.) [a “genuine issue” must relate to a material fact or facts]

Costs

(R.) v. Children’s Aid Society of the Niagara Region(2003), 34 R.F.L. (5th) 62 (Ont. C.A.) [It is not usual for costs to be awarded in child protection cases where an applicant is unsuccessful. Where unsuccessful parties are motivated by the best interests of the children a “no costs” award may be appropriate.]

Children’s Aid Society of Ottawa-Carleton v. S. and P.,(2003), 39 R.F.L. (5th) 209 (Ont. Div. Ct.)

[(a) The rationale for making child protection cases an exception to the presumptive entitlement to costs stems from the fact that a Society has a statutory obligation to initiate and pursue proceedings where there is reason to believe a child is in need of protection and it should not be dissuaded from the pursuit of its statutory mandate by cost considerations.

(b) The wording of r. 24 (2) is unequivocal that the presumptive entitlement to costs does not apply in child protection cases. Consequently, even between parents, for costs to be awarded there must be something more than merely the outcome of the case.]
